title: THE DAILY SHOW writer Daniel Radosh and editor Lauren Beckett Jackson Interview
description: McEric sits down with THE DAILY SHOW writer Daniel Radosh and editor Lauren Beckett Jackson for an interview Read the full article on AICN Comedy Central‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Daily Show‚Äù has been on-air for almost thirty years, garnering 26 PrimeTime Emmy Awards and several Peabody Awards for its writing and execution. Many are familiar with the show‚Äôs blend of current news commentary and informational journalism from comedians like Jon Stewart, Stephen Colbert, Steve Carrell, John Oliver, Samatha Bee, Roy Wood, Jr, Rob Riggle, Jordan Klepper, Wyatt Cenac, Hasan Minhaj, Larry Whitmore, Lewis Black, Desi Lydic, Ronny Chieng, Michael Kosta, and a bevy of others. ‚ÄúThe Daily Show‚Äôs‚Äù audience has grown up alongside the show, with viewership now skewing in higher age demographics than the coveted 18-34 bracket it dominated during its inception. That maturity is reflected in the current iteration of the show, with Stewart hosting on Monday‚Äôs while the rest of ‚ÄúThe Best F**king News Team‚Äù fill in the remainder of the week. ‚ÄúThe Daily Show‚Äù is a bit of a misnomer as the show broadcasts nightly on Comedy Central (or Paramount+ for those living in the streaming age) from Monday to Thursday. I suppose ‚ÄúThe Intermittent Show‚Äù just doesn‚Äôt have the same ring to it. ‚ÄúThe Daily Show‚Äù is not unique in its position as a satirical news program, however it remains the definitive iteration of the format. Everyone knows about ‚ÄúThe Daily Show,‚Äù love it or hate it. A foundational pillar of the show‚Äôs ubiquity and popularity is in the writing and execution of the show, which stands head and shoulders above its contemporaries. ¬† I was honored to speak with senior writer Daniel Radosh Finish the article on AICN
author: McEric

title: Scott Adkins Talks DIABLO
description: Scott Adkins talks with McEric about his new action film, DIABLO Read the full article on AICN If you‚Äôre a fan of current action films then you likely know the name Scott Adkins. He‚Äôs either kicked the ass of or had his ass kicked by every action star of the last five decades: Dolph Lundgren, Jackie Chan, Sylvester Stallone, Jean Claude Van Damme, Jet Li, and even Keanu Reeves. That‚Äôs right - he was the big guy with the grill in JOHN WICK CHAPTER 4.¬† Scott‚Äôs newest film is DIABLO, which hits theaters and on demand this Friday, June 13th. Conceived alongside action compatriot Marko Zaror, the film takes place in Colombia following Adkins as Kris, a former convict, who seeks to make good on a promise to a fallen friend, which runs him afoul of Zaror‚Äôs mercenary, El Corvo. This film isn‚Äôt just another straight-to-streaming no-budget piece of content - DIABLO delivers on every front. The fight scenes, choreographed by Zaror, are intense and deftly photographed, thanks to director Ernesto Diaz Espinoza. The gunplay is intense, the acting is top tier, and the film never lags.¬† ¬† Marko Zaror steals his scenes as El Corvo, a mercenary with an iron fist, literally. The six-foot-two Chilean action star has a chilling villain introduction, followed by a massive action scene in a sketchy hideout that plays out like a scene from TERMINATOR. He mows through assailants and bystanders alike with no emotion, only showing a hint of fear when Adkins‚Äôs Kris shows up to give him a real fight. El Corvo is fucking terrifying. Their final confrontation is a throwback to Finish the article on AICN
author: McEric

title: Review: Boyle's '28 Years Later' Reinvents the Zombie Genre (Again)
description: "There are many kinds of death... and some are better than others." üíÄ This is what happens when you get Danny Boyle & Alex Garland back together again! They will make more mad genius movies that push the boundaries of horror cinema and reinvent entire genres! Reunited after 18 years (they last made Sunshine together back in 2007), director Danny Boyle and screenwriter Alex Garland are ready to unleash 28 Years Later upon the world. This legacy sequel is a follow-up to their indie zombie movie classic 28 Days Later, wondering where things would be roughly 28 years after the rage virus wiped out the UK and how people, and zombies, would've evolved since then. I'm just going to say it ‚Äì this is the best of the 28 movies. Yes it's even better than 28 Days Later, and a much better sequel than 28 Weeks Later. What I was not ready for is how Boyle once again reinvents the zombie genre by trying out new ideas. They even finally drop "zombie" into the dialogue at one point, as this unkillable rage virus has turned humans into something else entirely. In many ways, 28 Years Later is an homage to [‚Ä¶]
author: Alex Billington

title: Remember This in 2009? 'Trainwreck: Balloon Boy' Netflix Doc Trailer
description: "What if my stupid experiment kills my son?" Who remembers this story? Of course we all do... How could anyone forget?! Netflix has revealed an official trailer for the doc Trainwreck: Balloon Boy, the next in their Trainwreck series of unforgettable moments from history. A homemade flying saucer lifts off, and a 6-year-old boy might be inside. National panic ensues when the media begins to cover it non-stop ‚Äî but what truly happened? This documentary investigates the real story of the Heene Family. It is made by filmmaker Gillian Pachter and delves into this breaking news story in October 2009. A dad claims his son is trapped in a runaway helium balloon - a "flying saucer" from his backyard. News helicopters follow the chase live once they spot the silver UFO. However, the balloon lands safely and there's no one inside, sparking outrage at the family as the story becomes one of America's most infamous hoaxes. The boy was just hiding in the attic all along. It makes me sad they had go to through this ‚Äì especially when everyone really was safe and sound. Here's the official trailer (+ poster) for Gillian Pachter's doc Trainwreck: Balloon Boy, from YouTube: [‚Ä¶]
author: Alex Billington
